headline.main: TASS REPORTS 'SPACE TUGBOAT' IS ATTACHED TO SALYUT STATION

results.snippet: The two Soviet astronauts aboard the Salyut 7 space station opened doors to a large attached module yesterday in a development that is expected to afford greater capacity, maneuverability and flexibility to the Soviet Union's manned space...
results.lead_paragraph: The two Soviet astronauts aboard the Salyut 7 space station opened doors to a large attached module yesterday in a development that is expected to afford greater capacity, maneuverability and flexibility to the Soviet Union's manned space operations. In reporting the events, the official Soviet press agency Tass gave some of the most detailed descriptions to date on the methods and directions of the Soviet space-station program. Describing the module, known as Cosmos 1443, as a ''space tugboat,'' Tass said it was a two-part spacecraft with its own maneuvering jets and a section that could be returned to earth. The Cosmos module was said to weigh 20 tons, almost as much as the Salyut itself.

results.snippet: To the Editor:    When I was graduated from a Texas college in 1945, I got a job with American Airlines as an international agent.
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When I was graduated from a Texas college in 1945, I got a job with American Airlines as an international agent.

results.snippet: At a breakfast given for local politicians by Presidential hopeful John Glenn, as the candidate was making his inspirational remarks about the need for America to ''go for it,'' an uncommitted county chairman whispered his analysis of '84 politics:...
results.lead_paragraph: At a breakfast given for local politicians by Presidential hopeful John Glenn, as the candidate was making his inspirational remarks about the need for America to ''go for it,'' an uncommitted county chairman whispered his analysis of '84 politics: ''If Reagan stubs his toe, this guy Glenn could make it. For Mondale to make it, Reagan would have to break his leg.'' Covering a Presidential campaign 16 months before an election is fun. No necklaces of credentials, no camera crews loading up a chartered 727 ''zoo plane,'' no grim-faced men wired up with plugs in their ears, no closed doors or mysterious gaps in schedules marked ''staff time.''

results.snippet: The Democratic Presidential candidates were wooing teachers at the annual meeting of the National Education Association here the last few days, and the teachers said they were delighted to see education back at the top of the nation's agenda.  ...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Democratic Presidential candidates were wooing teachers at the annual meeting of the National Education Association here the last few days, and the teachers said they were delighted to see education back at the top of the nation's agenda. Most teachers, however, denounced President Reagan's interest in the issue as highly opportunistic, arguing that he was making political hay by criticizing them and their union, which has long been pleading for more Federal attention to education. Ada Mae Karlberg, a third-grade teacher in Bucks County, Pa., outside Philadelphia, predicted, ''Ronald Reagan will emphasize education for about as long as it helps him focus negative attention on the Democratic candidates.'' Russell D. Clayton of Newton, Iowa, an eighth-grade teacher who has been registered as a Republican for 30 years, said he voted for Mr. Reagan in 1980 but would not do so again. Of the President's campaign for excellence in education, Mr. Clayton said, ''I think he is trying to save himself, to make amends, but it's kind of late.''

headline.main: REAGAN IMPLIES THAT N.E.A. LESSONS ARE AIMED AT BRAINWASHING STUDENTS

results.snippet: President Reagan, continuing his offensive on education issues, accused the nation's largest teachers union today of efforts aimed at ''brainwashing American schoolchildren.''   Mr. Reagan, who said the union, the National Education Association,...

byline.original: By DAVID SHRIBMAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan, continuing his offensive on education issues, accused the nation's largest teachers union today of efforts aimed at ''brainwashing American schoolchildren.'' Mr. Reagan, who said the union, the National Education Association, was trying to ''manipulate curriculum for propaganda purposes,'' made his remarks at the national convention of a rival union, the American Federation of Teachers. Although the N.E.A., long identified with the Democratic Party, was not specifically named in the President's speech in the Bonaventure Hotel here, it was clear that his remarks were aimed at the group, which has prepared curriculums dealing with nuclear war and racial issues. ''You stand in bright contrast to those who have promoted curriculum guides that seem to be more aimed at frightening and brainwashing American schoolchildren than at fostering learning and stimulating balanced, intelligent debate,'' Mr. Reagan told the convention, which is being attended by 2,340 delegates.

headline.main: First Night Launching Set for Space Shuttle

results.snippet: The first night launching and landing of the space shuttle should provide a spectacular visual show for Americans, but the rest of the eighth shuttle mission will not have a lot of ''pizazz,'' Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, the mission's...
results.lead_paragraph: The first night launching and landing of the space shuttle should provide a spectacular visual show for Americans, but the rest of the eighth shuttle mission will not have a lot of ''pizazz,'' Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, the mission's commander, said today at a news conference with the rest of the crew of five astronauts. ''I think we have an extremely important mission,'' Captain Truly said.

results.snippet: ONLY hours before Capt. Richard H. Truly flew the space shuttle Columbia to a safe landing on a dry lake bed in California two years ago he was beset by the fear that he was developing motion sickness.  Indeed, at least a third of the astronauts...
results.lead_paragraph: ONLY hours before Capt. Richard H. Truly flew the space shuttle Columbia to a safe landing on a dry lake bed in California two years ago he was beset by the fear that he was developing motion sickness. Indeed, at least a third of the astronauts who have flown in space have been beset by feelings of dizziness and nausea, and for centuries, many otherwise dauntless travelers, from skippers of ocean going vessels to racing car drivers, have been similarly humbled. Now, however, a new method for administering drugs, a procedure called transdermal medication, has been developed that uses neither pills nor injections but rather lets the medicine seep through the skin. It is not only helping astronauts and other travelers overcome their occasional bouts of motion sickness, disorientation and malaise. But its apparent success in that area has encouraged at least six pharmaceutical houses to work toward using transdermal medication for cancer chemotherapy, duodenal ulcers, glaucoma, asthma, allergies, hypertension and diabetes, as well as contraception.

headline.main: 500 AT NASA MUSEUM HONOR THE CHALLENGER CREW

results.snippet: ''This is one of those occasions which is pure joy -to welcome back these people who have been a little bit outside our world,'' said Phillip S. Hughes, the under secretary of the Smithsonsian Institution, as he looked out over the the crowd of...
results.lead_paragraph: ''This is one of those occasions which is pure joy -to welcome back these people who have been a little bit outside our world,'' said Phillip S. Hughes, the under secretary of the Smithsonsian Institution, as he looked out over the the crowd of more than 500 people who had gathered in the Langley Theater of the National Air and Space Museum Monday evening. It was a party in honor of the crew of the space shuttle Challenger, sponsored by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Smithsonian, the Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues and the Wonder Woman Foundation. A number of Washington organizations have been seeking a way to honor Dr. Sally K. Ride, the first American woman in space. But Dr. Ride has been insistent that she not be separated from the the rest of the Challenger's crew - Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, the commander; Capt. Frederick H. Hauck, also of the Navy, the pilot; Col. John M. Fabian of the Air Force and Dr. Norman E. Thagard, a civilian.

headline.main: Space Agency Enters The Stamp Business

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which drummed three men out of the astronaut corps for smuggling postal stamps to the moon, is going into the stamp-selling business itself on the mission of the space shuttle Challenger next...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which drummed three men out of the astronaut corps for smuggling postal stamps to the moon, is going into the stamp-selling business itself on the mission of the space shuttle Challenger next month. The eighth flight in the shuttle series will carry 250,000 of the cacheted covers ''depending on space availability,'' a space agency announcement said Tuesday.

headline.main: 2 MUSEUMS TO ADD BALANCE TO SOHO

results.snippet: WITH the pending arrival of not one but two contemporary museums in its midst, SoHo is ripening as the center for nonprofit activity in contemporary art, a development that balances nicely its bustling commercial side. On Sept. 23, the New Museum...
results.lead_paragraph: WITH the pending arrival of not one but two contemporary museums in its midst, SoHo is ripening as the center for nonprofit activity in contemporary art, a development that balances nicely its bustling commercial side. On Sept. 23, the New Museum of Contemporary Art, founded in 1976 by Marcia Tucker, will move from its outgrown 14th Street quarters to 583 Broadway, between Houston and Prince Streets, and early in 1985 Edward R. Broida, a new but very determined collector from California, will open his own museum just four blocks away in a four-story building at 130 Prince Street. The two museums will join such nonprofit SoHo institutions as the Drawing Center, the Clocktower, the Kitchen and the SoHo Center for the Visual Arts in a complex network of ''alternative'' exhibition spaces. Another alternative organization, Artists Space, is thinking of moving to SoHo, and within shouting distance, though technically in TriBeCa, are Franklin Furnace and the Alternative Museum. But the two new museums, with their collecting, archival and publishing activities, should give ballast to SoHo as an area where contemporary art may be studied in some depth, as well as viewed and purchased.

headline.main: U.S. Returns Stamps To Former Astronauts

results.snippet: The Federal Government has returned 359 stamped envelopes that could be worth half a million dollars to the three astronauts who took them to the moon in 1971.   The Justice Department decided it had no grounds for fighting a lawsuit filed in...
results.lead_paragraph: The Federal Government has returned 359 stamped envelopes that could be worth half a million dollars to the three astronauts who took them to the moon in 1971. The Justice Department decided it had no grounds for fighting a lawsuit filed in February by one former astronaut, Alfred M. Worden, for recovery of the covers, as they are called in philatelic circles. Mr. Worden agreed to drop the suit.

results.snippet: ''Balloonsbury, N.J.'' will be the official postmark and legal name of the Hunterdon County commmunity of Bloomsbury next weekend. That is when 65 hot-air balloons will be competing in the Northeast Regional Balloon Championships and the 200th...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Balloonsbury, N.J.'' will be the official postmark and legal name of the Hunterdon County commmunity of Bloomsbury next weekend. That is when 65 hot-air balloons will be competing in the Northeast Regional Balloon Championships and the 200th anniversary of balloon flight will be observed. Last year, the races drew 45,000 people, some from as far away as 200 miles; 65,000 people are expected this year. The spectacle of the balloons being launched in rapid succession and filling the sky will be accompanied by activities and entertainment for earthbound enthusiasts.
